Tropical Principal Component Analysis
and its Application to Phylogenetics

Ruriko Yoshida ‚ÄÉ‚ÄÉ Leon Zhang ‚ÄÉ‚ÄÉ Xu Zhang
Abstract

Principal component analysis is a widely-used method for the dimensionality reduction of a given data set in a high-dimensional Euclidean space. Here we define and analyze two analogues of principal component analysis in the setting of tropical geometry. In one approach, we study the Stiefel tropical linear space of fixed dimension closest to the data points in the tropical projective torus; in the other approach, we consider the tropical polytope with a fixed number of vertices closest to the data points. We then give approximative algorithms for both approaches and apply them to phylogenetics, testing the methods on simulated phylogenetic data and on an empirical dataset of Apicomplexa genomes.

1 Introduction

Principal component analysis (PCA) is a popular and robust method for reducing the dimension of a high-dimensional data set. Given a positive integer s‚àà‚Ñïùë†‚Ñïs\in\mathbb{N} and a collection of data points in a high-dimensional Euclidean space ‚Ñùesuperscript‚Ñùùëí\mathbb{R}^{e}, the procedure projects the data points onto a plane of fixed dimension s‚àí1ùë†1s-1, which is obtained by minimizing the sum of squared distances between each point in the dataset and its orthogonal projection onto the plane. This linear plane is a vector translate of some (s‚àí1)ùë†1(s-1)-dimensional linear subspace; PCA also constructs an orthonormal basis for that subspace whose vectors are called principal components. The low-dimensional plane is thus described by an (s√óe)ùë†ùëí(s\times e)-dimensional matrix, whose first s‚àí1ùë†1s-1 rows are the principal components and whose last row is the translation vector.

In this paper we propose two analogous approaches to a principal component analysis in the setting of tropical geometry. Given a positive integer sùë†s and a collection of data points in the tropical projective torus, our tropical principal component analyses seek a tropically-geometric object, as close as possible to the data points in the tropical metric dt‚Äãrsubscriptùëëùë°ùëüd_{tr}. In both cases, furthermore, this tropically-geometric object will be described by an (s√óe)ùë†ùëí(s\times e)-dimensional matrix.

Classically, a full-rank matrix of shape (s√óe)ùë†ùëí(s\times e) with s<eùë†ùëís<e defines an sùë†s-dimensional linear subspace of ‚Ñùesuperscript‚Ñùùëí\mathbb{R}^{e} via the span of its rows. This subspace is also described by the Pl√ºcker coordinates of the matrix. Tropically, on the other hand, these two notions diverge: the tropical Pl√ºcker coordinates of a tropical matrix produce a Stiefel tropical linear space, defined in [7], while the row-span of the matrix yields a tropical polytope. These two notions give rise to our two interpretations of tropical principal component analysis.

In Section 2, we discuss the basics of tropical geometry that we use throughout this paper. We also review the interpretation of the space of equidistant trees as a tropical linear space.

We then describe our first approach to a tropical principal component analysis in Section 3, as the Stiefel tropical linear space closest to the data points under the tropical metric dt‚Äãrsubscriptùëëùë°ùëüd_{tr}. We give an exact description for an (e‚àí1)ùëí1(e-1)st order tropical PCA of eùëíe points in terms of the tropical volume, originally introduced in [6]. We also describe an heuristic algorithm to approximate a best-fit Stiefel tropical linear space of a given dimension.

Next, in Section 4, we discuss a tropical principal component analysis in terms of best-fit tropical polytopes. We reformulate the problem of finding a best-fit tropical polytope in terms of a mixed integer programming problem, then describe an approximative algorithm similar to the above.

We then apply these methods to phylogenetics. The space of rooted equidistant phylogenetic trees with mùëöm leaves is naturally embedded into a tropical projective torus as a tropical linear space, so that collections of phylogenetic trees form a natural tropical dataset. We apply the approximative algorithms for both methods of tropical PCA on a simulated phylogenetic dataset in Section 5, and on an empirical dataset of Apicomplexa genomes in Section 6. In our tropical polytope approach, equidistant trees remain ultrametrics after projection, and so we examine the distribution of tree topologies in that case.

2.1 Tropical convexity

We next review some basic definitions from tropical convexity.

A subset SùëÜS of ‚Ñùesuperscript‚Ñùùëí\mathbb{R}^{e} is called tropically convex if it contains the point a‚äôx‚äïb‚äôydirect-sumdirect-productùëéùë•direct-productùëèùë¶a\odot x\oplus b\odot y for all x,y‚ààSùë•ùë¶ùëÜx,y\in S and all a,b‚àà‚Ñùùëéùëè‚Ñùa,b\in\mathbb{R}. The tropical convex hull or tropical polytope of a given subset V‚äÇ‚Ñùeùëâsuperscript‚ÑùùëíV\subset\mathbb{R}^{e} is the smallest tropically convex subset containing VùëâV of ‚Ñùesuperscript‚Ñùùëí\mathbb{R}^{e}. We write it as tconv‚Äã(V)tconvùëâ{\rm tconv}(V). The tropical convex hull of VùëâV coincides with the set of all tropical linear combinations

tconv‚Äã(V)={a1‚äôv1‚äïa2‚äôv2‚äï‚ãØ‚äïar‚äôvr:v1,‚Ä¶,vr‚ààV‚Äã¬†and¬†‚Äãa1,‚Ä¶,ar‚àà‚Ñù}.tconvùëâconditional-setdirect-sumdirect-productsubscriptùëé1subscriptùë£1direct-productsubscriptùëé2subscriptùë£2‚ãØdirect-productsubscriptùëéùëüsubscriptùë£ùëüformulae-sequencesubscriptùë£1‚Ä¶subscriptùë£ùëüùëâ¬†and¬†subscriptùëé1‚Ä¶subscriptùëéùëü‚Ñù{\rm tconv}(V)=\{a_{1}\odot v_{1}\oplus a_{2}\odot v_{2}\oplus\cdots\oplus a_{r}\odot v_{r}:v_{1},\ldots,v_{r}\in V\text{ and }a_{1},\ldots,a_{r}\in\mathbb{R}\}.

Any tropically convex subset SùëÜS of ‚Ñùesuperscript‚Ñùùëí\mathbb{R}^{e} is closed under tropical scalar multiplication, ‚Ñù‚äôS‚äÜSdirect-product‚ÑùùëÜùëÜ\mathbb{R}\odot S\subseteq S. 2.1.1 Tropical linear spaces

Our treatment of this topic largely follows [14, Sections 3 and 4].

Definition 2.3.

    (Exchange relation.) For any (d‚àí1)ùëë1(d-1)-subset œÉùúé\sigma and any (d+1)ùëë1(d+1)-subset œÑùúè\tau of [e]delimited-[]ùëí[e], the maximum

Definition 2.4.

Let p:[e]d‚Üí‚Ñù‚à™{‚àí‚àû}:ùëù‚Üísuperscriptdelimited-[]ùëíùëë‚Ñùp:[e]^{d}\to\mathbb{R}\cup\{-\infty\} be a tropical Pl√ºcker vector. In order to consider a ‚Äútropical principal component analysis‚Äù, as described at the beginning of this section, we must be able to project onto a tropical linear space. This projection operation is described by the Red and Blue Rules. From [14, Theorem 15] we have:

Then w‚ààLpùë§subscriptùêøùëùw\in L_{p}, and any other x‚ààLpùë•subscriptùêøùëùx\in L_{p} satisfies d‚Äã(u,x)‚â•d‚Äã(u,w)ùëëùë¢ùë•ùëëùë¢ùë§d(u,x)\geq d(u,w). In other words, wùë§w attains the minimum distance of any point in LpsubscriptùêøùëùL_{p} to uùë¢u.

Theorem 2.8 (The Red Rule).

Let p:[e]d‚Üí‚Ñù¬Ø:ùëù‚Üísuperscriptdelimited-[]ùëíùëë¬Ø‚Ñùp:[e]^{d}\to\overline{\mathbb{R}} be a tropical Pl√ºcker vector and LpsubscriptùêøùëùL_{p} its associated tropical linear space in ‚Ñùe/‚Ñù‚Äãùüèsuperscript‚Ñùùëí‚Ñù1\mathbb{R}^{e}/\mathbb{R}{\bf 1}. Fix u‚àà‚Ñùe/‚Ñù‚Äãùüèùë¢superscript‚Ñùùëí‚Ñù1u\in\mathbb{R}^{e}/\mathbb{R}{\bf 1}. Let vùë£v be the all-zeros vector. For every (d+1)ùëë1(d+1)-sized subset œÑùúè\tau of [e]delimited-[]ùëí[e], compute max‚Å°p‚Äã(œÑ‚àíœÑi)+uœÑiùëùùúèsubscriptùúèùëñsubscriptùë¢subscriptùúèùëñ\max p({\tau-\tau_{i}})+u_{\tau_{i}}. If this maximum is unique, attained with index œÑisubscriptùúèùëñ\tau_{i}, then let Œ≥œÑ,œÑisubscriptùõæùúèsubscriptùúèùëñ\gamma_{\tau,\tau_{i}} be the positive difference between the second maximum and this maximum, and set vœÑi=max‚Å°(vœÑi,Œ≥œÑ,œÑi)subscriptùë£subscriptùúèùëñsubscriptùë£subscriptùúèùëñsubscriptùõæùúèsubscriptùúèùëñv_{\tau_{i}}=\max(v_{\tau_{i}},\gamma_{\tau,\tau_{i}}).

Then vùë£v gives the difference between uùë¢u and a closest point of LpsubscriptùêøùëùL_{p}. In particular, if wùë§w is the point in LpsubscriptùêøùëùL_{p} returned by the Blue Rule, we have

u=w+v.ùë¢ùë§ùë£u=w+v.

We write œÄLpsubscriptùúãsubscriptùêøùëù\pi_{L_{p}} as the projection function which takes a point u‚àà‚Ñùe/‚Ñù‚Äãùüèùë¢superscript‚Ñùùëí‚Ñù1u\in\mathbb{R}^{e}/\mathbb{R}{\bf 1} and returns the nearest point w‚ààLpùë§subscriptùêøùëùw\in L_{p} given by the Blue Rule.

Example 2.9.

Let Aùê¥A be the matrix of Example 2.6, with pùëùp and LpsubscriptùêøùëùL_{p} its associated tropical Pl√ºcker vector and Stiefel tropical linear space. Let uùë¢u be the point (1,‚àí2,3)‚àà‚Ñùe/‚Ñù‚Äãùüè123superscript‚Ñùùëí‚Ñù1(1,-2,3)\in\mathbb{R}^{e}/\mathbb{R}{\bf 1}.

The Red Rule constructs a vector vùë£v as follows. First, we begin with v=(0,0,0)ùë£000v=(0,0,0). Next we take the set œÑ=[e]ùúèdelimited-[]ùëí\tau=[e] and compute max‚Å°(p‚Äã({2,3})+u1,p‚Äã({1,3})+u2,p‚Äã({1,2})+u3)=max‚Å°(3+1,4‚àí2,2+3)=5.ùëù23subscriptùë¢1ùëù13subscriptùë¢2ùëù12subscriptùë¢33142235\max(p(\{2,3\})+u_{1},p(\{1,3\})+u_{2},p(\{1,2\})+u_{3})=\max(3+1,4-2,2+3)=5. Now Theorem 2.8 states that u=w+vùë¢ùë§ùë£u=w+v, which is easily verified to hold.

Definition 2.10.

Let v=(v1,‚Ä¶,ve)ùë£subscriptùë£1‚Ä¶subscriptùë£ùëív=(v_{1},\ldots,v_{e}) be a real vector, and define the tropical linear functional ‚®Å(‚àívi)‚äóxidirect-sumtensor-productsubscriptùë£ùëñsubscriptùë•ùëñ\bigoplus(-v_{i})\otimes x_{i}. We call any ‚Ñã‚Ñã\mathcal{H} obtained in this way a tropical hyperplane.

Remark 2.11.

Let Aùê¥A be a tropical matrix of dimensions (e‚àí1)√óeùëí1ùëí(e-1)\times e. Then the Stiefel tropical linear space of Aùê¥A is a tropical hyperplane. Furthermore, any tropical hyperplane is the Stiefel tropical linear space of such a tropical matrix Aùê¥A.

2.2 A tropical interpretation for phylogenetic trees

In this section we describe some of the tropical aspects underlying the study of phylogenetic trees. Our treatment of this subject largely follows [18, Section 4.3].

Definition 2.12.

A dissimilarity map dùëëd is a function d:[m]√ó[m]‚Üí‚Ñù‚â•0:ùëë‚Üídelimited-[]ùëödelimited-[]ùëösubscript‚Ñùabsent0d:[m]\times[m]\to\mathbb{R}_{\geq 0} such that d‚Äã(i,i)=0ùëëùëñùëñ0d(i,i)=0 and d‚Äã(i,j)=d‚Äã(j,i)‚â•0ùëëùëñùëóùëëùëóùëñ0d(i,j)=d(j,i)\geq 0 for each i,j‚àà[m]ùëñùëódelimited-[]ùëöi,j\in[m]. If, furthermore, we have that d‚Äã(i,j)‚â§d‚Äã(i,k)+d‚Äã(k,j)ùëëùëñùëóùëëùëñùëòùëëùëòùëód(i,j)\leq d(i,k)+d(k,j) for all i,j,k‚àà[m]ùëñùëóùëòdelimited-[]ùëöi,j,k\in[m], we call dùëëd a metric. Note that for convenience we often write di‚Äãjsubscriptùëëùëñùëód_{ij} for the term d‚Äã(i,j)ùëëùëñùëód(i,j).

We can represent a dissimilarity map dùëëd by an m√ómùëöùëöm\times m matrix Dùê∑D whose (i,j)ùëñùëó(i,j)th entry is di‚Äãjsubscriptùëëùëñùëód_{ij}. Because Dùê∑D is clearly symmetric and all diagonal entries are trivial, there is a natural embedding of dùëëd into the tropical space ‚Ñùe=R(m2)superscript‚ÑùùëísuperscriptùëÖbinomialùëö2\mathbb{R}^{e}=R^{\binom{m}{2}}.

In fact, the condition of being a metric is intrinsically tropical.

Lemma 2.13.

Let d:[m]√ó[m]‚Üí‚Ñù‚â•0:ùëë‚Üídelimited-[]ùëödelimited-[]ùëösubscript‚Ñùabsent0d:[m]\times[m]\to\mathbb{R}_{\geq 0} be a dissimilarity metric and Dùê∑D its corresponding matrix. Then dùëëd is a metric iff ‚àíD‚äô‚àíD=‚àíD-D\odot-D=-D.

Proof.

The (i,j)ùëñùëó(i,j)th entry of ‚àíD‚äô‚àíD-D\odot-D is equal to

‚®Åk=1m‚àídi‚Äãk‚àídk‚Äãj=maxk‚àà[m]‚Å°(‚àídi‚Äãk‚àídk‚Äãj).superscriptsubscriptdirect-sumùëò1ùëösubscriptùëëùëñùëòsubscriptùëëùëòùëósubscriptùëòdelimited-[]ùëösubscriptùëëùëñùëòsubscriptùëëùëòùëó\bigoplus_{k=1}^{m}-d_{ik}-d_{kj}=\max_{k\in[m]}(-d_{ik}-d_{kj}).

In particular, we note that the (i,j)ùëñùëó(i,j)th entry of ‚àíD‚äô‚àíD-D\odot-D is at least as large as ‚àídi‚Äãj=‚àídi‚Äãi‚àídi‚Äãjsubscriptùëëùëñùëósubscriptùëëùëñùëñsubscriptùëëùëñùëó-d_{ij}=-d_{ii}-d_{ij}. Now a simple negation of the definition shows that dùëëd is a metric iff ‚àídi‚Äãj‚â•maxk‚àà[m]‚Å°(‚àídi‚Äãk‚àídk‚Äãj)subscriptùëëùëñùëósubscriptùëòdelimited-[]ùëösubscriptùëëùëñùëòsubscriptùëëùëòùëó-d_{ij}\geq\max_{k\in[m]}(-d_{ik}-d_{kj}). ‚àé

Definition 2.14.

Let T=(V,E)ùëáùëâùê∏T=(V,E) be a tree with mùëöm labeled leaves and no vertices of degree two. We call such a tree a phylogenetic tree.

Definition 2.15.

Let TùëáT be a phylogenetic tree with mùëöm leaves labeled with the elements of [m]delimited-[]ùëö[m], and assign a length ‚Ñìe‚àà‚Ñùsubscript‚Ñìùëí‚Ñù\ell_{e}\in\mathbb{R} to each edge eùëíe of TùëáT. Let d:[m]√ó[m]‚Üí‚Ñù:ùëë‚Üídelimited-[]ùëödelimited-[]ùëö‚Ñùd:[m]\times[m]\to\mathbb{R} be defined so that di‚Äãjsubscriptùëëùëñùëód_{ij} is the total length of the unique path from leaf iùëñi to leaf jùëój. We call a function dùëëd obtained in this way a tree distance. If, furthermore, each entry of the distance matrix Dùê∑D is nonnegative, then dùëëd is in fact a metric. We call such a dùëëd a tree metric. As before, we can embed Dùê∑D into ‚Ñùesuperscript‚Ñùùëí\mathbb{R}^{e}.

Of course, any tree distance differs from a tree metric by some scalar multiple of ùüè1{\bf 1}. Hence the sets of tree distances and tree metrics coincide in ‚Ñù/ùüè‚Äã‚Ñù‚Ñù1‚Ñù\mathbb{R}/{\bf 1}\mathbb{R}.

Definition 2.16.

Let d:[m]√ó[m]‚Üí‚Ñù‚â•0:ùëë‚Üídelimited-[]ùëödelimited-[]ùëösubscript‚Ñùabsent0d:[m]\times[m]\to\mathbb{R}_{\geq 0} be a metric which satisfies the following strengthening of the triangle inequality for each choice of i,j,k‚àà[m]ùëñùëóùëòdelimited-[]ùëöi,j,k\in[m]:

d‚Äã(i,k)‚â§max‚Å°(d‚Äã(i,j),d‚Äã(j,k)).ùëëùëñùëòùëëùëñùëóùëëùëóùëòd(i,k)\leq\max(d(i,j),d(j,k)).

We call such a metric an ultrametric. Let ùí∞msubscriptùí∞ùëö\mathcal{U}_{m} denote the collection of all ultrametrics in ‚Ñùe/ùüè‚Äã‚Ñùsuperscript‚Ñùùëí1‚Ñù\mathbb{R}^{e}/{\bf 1}\mathbb{R}.

It is well-known that all ultrametrics are tree metrics. In fact, all ultrametrics are derived from equidistant trees, where all leaves have the same distance to some distinguished root vertex. Furthermore, the tree metric of an equidistant tree is an ultrametric; hence ultrametrics and equidistant trees convey equivalent information.

Let LmsubscriptùêøùëöL_{m} denote the subspace of ‚Ñùesuperscript‚Ñùùëí\mathbb{R}^{e} defined by the linear equations xi‚Äãj‚àíxi‚Äãk+xj‚Äãk=0subscriptùë•ùëñùëósubscriptùë•ùëñùëòsubscriptùë•ùëóùëò0x_{ij}-x_{ik}+x_{jk}=0 for 1‚â§i<j<k‚â§m1ùëñùëóùëòùëö1\leq i<j<k\leq m. The tropicalization Trop‚Äã(Lm)‚äÜ‚Ñùe/‚Ñù‚ÄãùüèTropsubscriptùêøùëösuperscript‚Ñùùëí‚Ñù1\text{Trop}(L_{m})\subseteq\mathbb{R}^{e}/\mathbb{R}{\bf 1} is the tropical linear space consisting of points (v12,v13,‚Ä¶,vm‚àí1,m)subscriptùë£12subscriptùë£13‚Ä¶subscriptùë£ùëö1ùëö(v_{12},v_{13},\ldots,v_{m-1,m}) such that max‚Å°(vi‚Äãj,vi‚Äãk,vj‚Äãk)subscriptùë£ùëñùëósubscriptùë£ùëñùëòsubscriptùë£ùëóùëò\max(v_{ij},v_{ik},v_{jk}) is obtained at least twice for all triples i,j,k‚àà[m]ùëñùëóùëòdelimited-[]ùëöi,j,k\in[m].

Remark 2.17.

Experts in tropical geometry will note that the tropical linear space Trop‚Äã(Lm)Tropsubscriptùêøùëö\text{Trop}(L_{m}) corresponds to the graphic matroid of the complete graph KmsubscriptùêæùëöK_{m}.

Theorem 2.18.

The image of ùí∞msubscriptùí∞ùëö\mathcal{U}_{m} in the tropical projective torus ‚Ñùe/‚Ñù‚Äãùüèsuperscript‚Ñùùëí‚Ñù1\mathbb{R}^{e}/\mathbb{R}{\bf 1} coincides with Trop‚Äã(Lm)Tropsubscriptùêøùëö\text{Trop}(L_{m}).

Proof.

Let (v12,v13,‚Ä¶,vm‚àí1,m)‚ààTrop‚Äã(Lm)subscriptùë£12subscriptùë£13‚Ä¶subscriptùë£ùëö1ùëöTropsubscriptùêøùëö(v_{12},v_{13},\ldots,v_{m-1,m})\in\text{Trop}(L_{m}). We may assume that each coordinate is nonnegative, so that this point corresponds to the image of a dissimilarity map dùëëd. To see that dùëëd is in fact an ultrametric, fix i,j,k‚àà[m]ùëñùëóùëòdelimited-[]ùëöi,j,k\in[m]. We know that max‚Å°(di‚Äãj,di‚Äãk,dk‚Äãj)subscriptùëëùëñùëósubscriptùëëùëñùëòsubscriptùëëùëòùëó\max(d_{ij},d_{ik},d_{kj}) is attained at least twice, by the definition of Trop‚Äã(Lm)Tropsubscriptùêøùëö\text{Trop}(L_{m}). If di‚Äãjsubscriptùëëùëñùëód_{ij} is one of these maximums then it must be equal to max‚Å°(di‚Äãk,dk‚Äãj)subscriptùëëùëñùëòsubscriptùëëùëòùëó\max(d_{ik},d_{kj}). If d‚Äã(i,j)ùëëùëñùëód(i,j) is not one of these maximums then it must be strictly less than max‚Å°(di‚Äãk,dk‚Äãj)subscriptùëëùëñùëòsubscriptùëëùëòùëó\max(d_{ik},d_{kj}). Either way, we have that di‚Äãj‚â§max‚Å°(di‚Äãk,dk‚Äãj)subscriptùëëùëñùëósubscriptùëëùëñùëòsubscriptùëëùëòùëód_{ij}\leq\max(d_{ik},d_{kj}). This shows that dùëëd is in fact an ultrametric, so that Trop‚Äã(Lm)‚äÜùí∞mTropsubscriptùêøùëösubscriptùí∞ùëö\text{Trop}(L_{m})\subseteq\mathcal{U}_{m}.

Let D¬Ø‚ààùí∞m¬Øùê∑subscriptùí∞ùëö\bar{D}\in\mathcal{U}_{m}. Then there exists some lifted ultrametric dùëëd with associated matrix Dùê∑D. Fix a choice of i,j,k‚àà[m]ùëñùëóùëòdelimited-[]ùëöi,j,k\in[m], and without loss of generality let i,jùëñùëói,j such that di‚Äãj=max‚Å°(di‚Äãj,di‚Äãk,dk‚Äãj)subscriptùëëùëñùëósubscriptùëëùëñùëósubscriptùëëùëñùëòsubscriptùëëùëòùëód_{ij}=\max(d_{ij},d_{ik},d_{kj}). Because dùëëd is an ultrametric, we have that di‚Äãj‚â§max‚Å°(di‚Äãk,dk‚Äãj)subscriptùëëùëñùëósubscriptùëëùëñùëòsubscriptùëëùëòùëód_{ij}\leq\max(d_{ik},d_{kj}). Hence in fact di‚Äãj=max‚Å°(di‚Äãk,dk‚Äãj)subscriptùëëùëñùëósubscriptùëëùëñùëòsubscriptùëëùëòùëód_{ij}=\max(d_{ik},d_{kj}), and the maximum of max‚Å°(di‚Äãj,di‚Äãk,dk‚Äãj)subscriptùëëùëñùëósubscriptùëëùëñùëòsubscriptùëëùëòùëó\max(d_{ij},d_{ik},d_{kj}) is attained at least twice. Thus Trop‚Äã(Lm)‚äáùí∞msubscriptùí∞ùëöTropsubscriptùêøùëö\text{Trop}(L_{m})\supseteq\mathcal{U}_{m}. ‚àé

In words, Theorem 2.18 states that the image of the space of labeled rooted trees is a tropical linear space. The set of equidistant trees thus has an intrinsic tropical structure.

3 Tropical PCA as a Stiefel tropical linear space

As noted in the introduction, one can interpret ordinary (s‚àí1)ùë†1(s-1)th principal component analysis as a method of dimensionality reduction, replacing data points with their projections onto the translate of some particularly well-fitting linear space of dimension s‚àí1ùë†1s-1. Classically, this translation of a well-fitted linear space can be described by an (s√óe)ùë†ùëí(s\times e)-dimensional matrix, whose first (s‚àí1)ùë†1(s-1) rows are the basis vectors of the linear space, and whose last row is a translation vector from the origin.

In analogy with the classical case, our approach to an (s‚àí1)ùë†1(s-1)th tropical principal component analysis is to replace data points with their tropical projections onto the best-fit Stiefel tropical linear space of dimension (s‚àí1)ùë†1(s-1), defined by a tropical matrix of size s√óeùë†ùëís\times e.

3.1 Best-fit tropical hyperplanes

We begin our discussion of tropical principal component analysis by considering a specific case: reducing by one the dimension of a collection of eùëíe datapoints in ‚Ñùe/‚Ñù‚Äãùüèsuperscript‚Ñùùëí‚Ñù1\mathbb{R}^{e}/\mathbb{R}{\bf 1}. In other words, we seek the (e‚àí1)ùëí1(e-1)th order tropical PCA, or a best-fit tropical hyperplane, for a collection of eùëíe data points in ‚Ñùe/‚Ñù‚Äãùüèsuperscript‚Ñùùëí‚Ñù1\mathbb{R}^{e}/\mathbb{R}{\bf 1}.

We require the following definition, from [6].

Definition 3.1.

Let Aùê¥A be an e√óeùëíùëíe\times e matrix with entries in ‚Ñù¬Ø¬Ø‚Ñù\overline{\mathbb{R}} whose rows correspond to eùëíe points in ‚Ñùe/‚Ñù‚Äãùüèsuperscript‚Ñùùëí‚Ñù1\mathbb{R}^{e}/\mathbb{R}{\bf 1}. The tropical volume of Aùê¥A is given by the expression

tvol¬†‚ÄãA:=‚®ÅœÉ‚ààSe‚àëai,œÉ‚Äã(i)‚àí‚®ÅœÑ‚ààSe‚àíœÉo‚Äãp‚Äãt‚àëai,œÑ‚Äã(i),assigntvol¬†ùê¥subscriptdirect-sumùúésubscriptùëÜùëísubscriptùëéùëñùúéùëñsubscriptdirect-sumùúèsubscriptùëÜùëísubscriptùúéùëúùëùùë°subscriptùëéùëñùúèùëñ\text{tvol\,}A:=\bigoplus_{\sigma\in S_{e}}\sum a_{i,\sigma(i)}-\bigoplus_{\tau\in S_{e}-\sigma_{opt}}\sum a_{i,\tau(i)},

where œÉo‚Äãp‚Äãtsubscriptùúéùëúùëùùë°\sigma_{opt} is an optimal permutation attaining the tropical determinant in the first tropical sum.

Recall that a square tropical matrix Aùê¥A is tropically singular if two distinct permutations attain the tropical determinant. The following, from [22, Lemma 5.1], is one of the earliest results in tropical geometry:

Lemma 3.2.

Let Aùê¥A be an e√óeùëíùëíe\times e tropical matrix whose rows represent eùëíe points of ‚Ñùe/‚Ñù‚Äãùüèsuperscript‚Ñùùëí‚Ñù1\mathbb{R}^{e}/\mathbb{R}{\bf 1}. Then Aùê¥A is tropically singular iff those kùëòk points lie on a tropical hyperplane in ‚Ñùe/‚Ñù‚Äãùüèsuperscript‚Ñùùëí‚Ñù1\mathbb{R}^{e}/\mathbb{R}{\bf 1}. In particular, tvol¬†‚Äã(A)=0tvol¬†ùê¥0\text{tvol\,}(A)=0 iff the eùëíe points lie on a common tropical hyperplane.

Of course, if our collection of eùëíe datapoints D(i)superscriptùê∑ùëñD^{(i)} lie on a common hyperplane, then this hyperplane is our (e‚àí1)ùëí1(e-1)th tropical PCA. This fact hints at some relationship between the tropical volume and the best fit hyperplane. In fact, this relationship is quite strong.

Theorem 3.3.

Let D(1),‚Ä¶,D(e)superscriptùê∑1‚Ä¶superscriptùê∑ùëíD^{(1)},\ldots,D^{(e)} be a collection of eùëíe points in ‚Ñùe/‚Ñù‚Äãùüèsuperscript‚Ñùùëí‚Ñù1\mathbb{R}^{e}/\mathbb{R}{\bf 1}. Then the best-fit hyperplane attains a distance from the eùëíe points equal to their tropical volume, and one such best-fit hyperplane is spanned by a choice of e‚àí1ùëí1e-1 of the points.

To prove this theorem, we first show that the tropical volume is an upper bound on the minimal distance of a best-fit tropical hyperplane.

Lemma 3.4.

Let D(1),‚Ä¶,D(e)superscriptùê∑1‚Ä¶superscriptùê∑ùëíD^{(1)},\ldots,D^{(e)} be a collection of eùëíe points in ‚Ñùe/‚Ñù‚Äãùüèsuperscript‚Ñùùëí‚Ñù1\mathbb{R}^{e}/\mathbb{R}{\bf 1}, and let Aùê¥A be the matrix whose i,jùëñùëói,jth entry is Dj(i)subscriptsuperscriptùê∑ùëñùëóD^{(i)}_{j}. Then there exists a hyperplane of distance tvol¬†‚ÄãAtvol¬†ùê¥\text{tvol\,}A from the data points, spanned by some choice of e‚àí1ùëí1e-1 of the points.

Proof.

Suppose that all eùëíe data points can be spanned by a single hyperplane. Then Lemma 3.2 tells us that this best-fit hyperplane is of distance tvol¬†‚ÄãA=0tvol¬†ùê¥0\text{tvol\,}A=0 from the data points.

Now suppose that the eùëíe data points do not lie on the same hyperplane. Without loss of generality, we may assume that the data points D(1),‚Ä¶,D(e)superscriptùê∑1‚Ä¶superscriptùê∑ùëíD^{(1)},\ldots,D^{(e)} are ordered so that œÉo‚Äãp‚Äãtsubscriptùúéùëúùëùùë°\sigma_{opt} in the above definition of the tropical volume is just the identity, and hence the tropical determinant is attained along the diagonal of Aùê¥A.

Let œÅùúå\rho attain the second maximum in the above definition of the tropical volume. Since œÅùúå\rho is not the identity, there must exist some jùëój such that œÅ‚Äã(j)‚â†jùúåùëóùëó\rho(j)\neq j. Let A‚Ä≤superscriptùê¥‚Ä≤A^{\prime} be the matrix obtained by deleting the jùëójth row from Aùê¥A, and let pùëùp and ‚Ñã‚Ñã\mathcal{H} the tropical Pl√ºcker vector and tropical hyperplane corresponding to A‚Ä≤superscriptùê¥‚Ä≤A^{\prime} as in Example 2.6. The total distance from HùêªH to our data points is just the distance from HùêªH to D(j)superscriptùê∑ùëóD^{(j)}, as all other data points are on HùêªH by construction.

We compute the difference vector between D(j)superscriptùê∑ùëóD^{(j)} and its projection onto HùêªH using the Red Rule (Theorem 2.8). The only possible choice for an eùëíe-sized subset œÑùúè\tau of [e]delimited-[]ùëí[e] is just œÑ=[e]ùúèdelimited-[]ùëí\tau=[e], and we need to compute the maximum and second-maximum values of p‚Äã([e]‚àíœÑi)+DœÑi(j)ùëùdelimited-[]ùëísubscriptùúèùëñsubscriptsuperscriptùê∑ùëósubscriptùúèùëñp({[e]-\tau_{i}})+D^{(j)}_{\tau_{i}}, taken over all choices of œÑi‚àà[e]subscriptùúèùëñdelimited-[]ùëí\tau_{i}\in[e]. For any such œÑisubscriptùúèùëñ\tau_{i}, we note that p‚Äã([e]‚àíœÑi)+DœÑi(j)ùëùdelimited-[]ùëísubscriptùúèùëñsubscriptsuperscriptùê∑ùëósubscriptùúèùëñp({[e]-\tau_{i}})+D^{(j)}_{\tau_{i}} is equal to

‚®ÅœÉ‚ààSd,œÉ‚Äã(j)=œÑi‚àëiDœÉ‚Äã(i)(i).subscriptdirect-sumformulae-sequenceùúésubscriptùëÜùëëùúéùëósubscriptùúèùëñsubscriptùëñsuperscriptsubscriptùê∑ùúéùëñùëñ\bigoplus_{\sigma\in S_{d},\;\sigma(j)=\tau_{i}}\sum_{i}D_{\sigma(i)}^{(i)}.

That is, pœÑ‚àíœÑi+DœÑi(j)subscriptùëùùúèsubscriptùúèùëñsuperscriptsubscriptùê∑subscriptùúèùëñùëóp_{\tau-\tau_{i}}+D_{\tau_{i}}^{(j)} is the tropical sum of all permutations which map œÑisubscriptùúèùëñ\tau_{i} to jùëój. In particular, œÑi=jsubscriptùúèùëñùëó\tau_{i}=j must yield the largest choice of pœÑ‚àíœÑi+DœÑi(j)subscriptùëùùúèsubscriptùúèùëñsuperscriptsubscriptùê∑subscriptùúèùëñùëóp_{\tau-\tau_{i}}+D_{\tau_{i}}^{(j)}, and the second-largest choice must be attained by œÑi=œÅ‚àí1‚Äã(j)subscriptùúèùëñsuperscriptùúå1ùëó\tau_{i}=\rho^{-1}(j). Hence the Red Rule implies that the distance between D(j)superscriptùê∑ùëóD^{(j)} and its projection is just the tropical volume, as desired. ‚àé

Remark 3.5.

In general, a best-fit Stiefel tropical linear space need not be unique. For example, in the proof of Lemma 3.4, there clearly must be at least two indices jùëój such that œÅ‚Äã(j)‚â†jùúåùëóùëó\rho(j)\neq j.

We next show that the tropical volume is also an upper bound. To do so, we first derive some intermediate results.

Lemma 3.6.

Let D(1),‚Ä¶,D(e)superscriptùê∑1‚Ä¶superscriptùê∑ùëíD^{(1)},\ldots,D^{(e)} be a collection of eùëíe points in ‚Ñùe/‚Ñù‚Äãùüèsuperscript‚Ñùùëí‚Ñù1\mathbb{R}^{e}/\mathbb{R}{\bf 1}, and let Aùê¥A be the e√óeùëíùëíe\times e tropical matrix whose i,jùëñùëói,jth entry is Dj(i)subscriptsuperscriptùê∑ùëñùëóD^{(i)}_{j}. Define the matrix A‚Ä≤superscriptùê¥‚Ä≤A^{\prime} whose i,jùëñùëói,jth entry equals p‚Äã([e]‚àí{i})+Di(j)ùëùdelimited-[]ùëíùëñsubscriptsuperscriptùê∑ùëóùëñp([e]-\{i\})+D^{(j)}_{i}. Then Aùê¥A and A‚Ä≤superscriptùê¥‚Ä≤A^{\prime} have the same tropical volume.

Proof.

We note that A‚Ä≤superscriptùê¥‚Ä≤A^{\prime} is obtained from Aùê¥A by transposition then adding some multiple of 1 to each row. Both of these operations preserve the tropical volume of a matrix. ‚àé

Now suppose that ‚Ñã‚Ñã\mathcal{H} is a tropical hyperplane in ‚Ñùe/‚Ñù‚Äãùüèsuperscript‚Ñùùëí‚Ñù1\mathbb{R}^{e}/\mathbb{R}{\bf 1}, and write its corresponding tropical Pl√ºcker vector as p‚Äã([e]‚àí{i})ùëùdelimited-[]ùëíùëñp([e]-\{i\}). We can calculate the distance Œ¥j‚Äã(‚Ñã)subscriptùõøùëó‚Ñã\delta_{j}(\mathcal{H}) of ‚Ñã‚Ñã\mathcal{H} from the jùëójth datapoint D(j)superscriptùê∑ùëóD^{(j)} by the Red Rule: the distance is given by

Œ¥j‚Äã(‚Ñã)=maxi‚Å°(p‚Äã([e]‚àí{i})+Di(j))‚àí2ndmaxi‚Äã(p‚Äã([e]‚àí{i})+Di(j)).subscriptùõøùëó‚Ñãsubscriptùëñùëùdelimited-[]ùëíùëñsubscriptsuperscriptùê∑ùëóùëñsubscript2ndmaxùëñùëùdelimited-[]ùëíùëñsubscriptsuperscriptùê∑ùëóùëñ\delta_{j}(\mathcal{H})=\max_{i}(p([e]-\{i\})+D^{(j)}_{i})-\text{2ndmax}_{i}(p([e]-\{i\})+D^{(j)}_{i}).

We write the total distance of ‚Ñã‚Ñã\mathcal{H} from our datapoints as d‚Äã(‚Ñã)ùëë‚Ñãd(\mathcal{H}). It is given by

d‚Äã(‚Ñã)=‚àëjŒ¥j‚Äã(‚Ñã)=‚àëj(maxi‚Å°(p‚Äã([e]‚àí{i})+Di(j))‚àí2ndmaxi‚Äã(p‚Äã([e]‚àí{i})+Di(j))).ùëë‚Ñãsubscriptùëósubscriptùõøùëó‚Ñãsubscriptùëósubscriptùëñùëùdelimited-[]ùëíùëñsubscriptsuperscriptùê∑ùëóùëñsubscript2ndmaxùëñùëùdelimited-[]ùëíùëñsubscriptsuperscriptùê∑ùëóùëñd(\mathcal{H})=\sum_{j}\delta_{j}(\mathcal{H})=\sum_{j}\left(\max_{i}(p([e]-\{i\})+D^{(j)}_{i})-\text{2ndmax}_{i}(p([e]-\{i\})+D^{(j)}_{i})\right).

We can rewrite the cost function d‚Äã(‚Ñã)ùëë‚Ñãd(\mathcal{H}) above by grouping together the summed and subtracted terms. For fixed jùëój, define Œ±j‚Äã(‚Ñã)=maxi‚Å°(p‚Äã([e]‚àí{i})+Di(j))subscriptùõºùëó‚Ñãsubscriptùëñùëùdelimited-[]ùëíùëñsubscriptsuperscriptùê∑ùëóùëñ\alpha_{j}(\mathcal{H})=\max_{i}(p([e]-\{i\})+D^{(j)}_{i}) and Œ≤j‚Äã(‚Ñã)=2ndmaxi‚Äã(p‚Äã([e]‚àí{i})+Di(j))subscriptùõΩùëó‚Ñãsubscript2ndmaxùëñùëùdelimited-[]ùëíùëñsubscriptsuperscriptùê∑ùëóùëñ\beta_{j}(\mathcal{H})=\text{2ndmax}_{i}(p([e]-\{i\})+D^{(j)}_{i}). Then Œ¥j‚Äã(‚Ñã)=Œ±j‚Äã(‚Ñã)‚àíŒ≤j‚Äã(‚Ñã)subscriptùõøùëó‚Ñãsubscriptùõºùëó‚ÑãsubscriptùõΩùëó‚Ñã\delta_{j}(\mathcal{H})=\alpha_{j}(\mathcal{H})-\beta_{j}(\mathcal{H}), and the cost function can also be written as

d‚Äã(‚Ñã)=‚àëjŒ¥j‚Äã(‚Ñã)=‚àëjŒ±j‚Äã(‚Ñã)‚àí‚àëjŒ≤j‚Äã(‚Ñã).ùëë‚Ñãsubscriptùëósubscriptùõøùëó‚Ñãsubscriptùëósubscriptùõºùëó‚ÑãsubscriptùëósubscriptùõΩùëó‚Ñãd(\mathcal{H})=\sum_{j}\delta_{j}(\mathcal{H})=\sum_{j}\alpha_{j}(\mathcal{H})-\sum_{j}\beta_{j}(\mathcal{H}).
Definition 3.7.

Fix jùëój in the cost function above, and let i1subscriptùëñ1i_{1} and i2subscriptùëñ2i_{2} be distinct indices such that Œ±j‚Äã(‚Ñã)=p‚Äã([e]‚àí{i1})+Di1(j)subscriptùõºùëó‚Ñãùëùdelimited-[]ùëísubscriptùëñ1subscriptsuperscriptùê∑ùëósubscriptùëñ1\alpha_{j}(\mathcal{H})=p([e]-\{i_{1}\})+D^{(j)}_{i_{1}} and Œ≤j‚Äã(‚Ñã)=p‚Äã([e]‚àí{i2})+Di2(j)subscriptùõΩùëó‚Ñãùëùdelimited-[]ùëísubscriptùëñ2subscriptsuperscriptùê∑ùëósubscriptùëñ2\beta_{j}(\mathcal{H})=p([e]-\{i_{2}\})+D^{(j)}_{i_{2}}. If Œ¥j‚Äã(‚Ñã)=0subscriptùõøùëó‚Ñã0\delta_{j}(\mathcal{H})=0, meaning that Œ±j‚Äã(‚Ñã)=Œ≤j‚Äã(‚Ñã)subscriptùõºùëó‚ÑãsubscriptùõΩùëó‚Ñã\alpha_{j}(\mathcal{H})=\beta_{j}(\mathcal{H}), we say that the two indices i1subscriptùëñ1i_{1} and i2subscriptùëñ2i_{2} appear in a tie for index jùëój. If there exists another index i3subscriptùëñ3i_{3} such that p‚Äã([e]‚àí{i3})+Di3(j)=Œ±j‚Äã(‚Ñã)=Œ≤j‚Äã(‚Ñã)ùëùdelimited-[]ùëísubscriptùëñ3subscriptsuperscriptùê∑ùëósubscriptùëñ3subscriptùõºùëó‚ÑãsubscriptùõΩùëó‚Ñãp([e]-\{i_{3}\})+D^{(j)}_{i_{3}}=\alpha_{j}(\mathcal{H})=\beta_{j}(\mathcal{H}), we call this a multiple tie for index jùëój; if there does not exist such an i3subscriptùëñ3i_{3}, we call this a two-way tie.

Note that, in the event of a tie, we may choose any two of the indices attaining the tie to correspond to Œ±j‚Äã(‚Ñã)subscriptùõºùëó‚Ñã\alpha_{j}(\mathcal{H}) and Œ≤j‚Äã(‚Ñã)subscriptùõΩùëó‚Ñã\beta_{j}(\mathcal{H}).

Lemma 3.8.

Let ‚Ñã‚Ñã\mathcal{H} be an optimal hyperplane in ‚Ñùe/‚Ñù‚Äãùüèsuperscript‚Ñùùëí‚Ñù1\mathbb{R}^{e}/\mathbb{R}{\bf 1}, and let pùëùp be its corresponding tropical Pl√ºcker vector. Choose an index iùëñi such that p‚Äã([e]‚àí{i})<Œ≤j‚â§Œ±jùëùdelimited-[]ùëíùëñsubscriptùõΩùëósubscriptùõºùëóp({[e]-\{i\}})<\beta_{j}\leq\alpha_{j} for all jùëój. Then we can perturb ‚Ñã‚Ñã\mathcal{H} to obtain a new best-fit hyperplane ‚Ñã‚Ä≤superscript‚Ñã‚Ä≤\mathcal{H}^{\prime} so that p‚Äã([e]‚àí{i})+Di(j)=Œ≤jùëùdelimited-[]ùëíùëñsuperscriptsubscriptùê∑ùëñùëósubscriptùõΩùëóp([e]-\{i\})+D_{i}^{(j)}=\beta_{j} for some jùëój, and this jùëój corresponds to a multiple tie.

Proof.

Because p‚Äã([e]‚àí{i})ùëùdelimited-[]ùëíùëñp({[e]-\{i\}}) does not appear in the cost function by assumption, by Remark 2.11 we can find a new hyperplane ‚Ñã‚Ä≤superscript‚Ñã‚Ä≤\mathcal{H}^{\prime} with the same tropical Pl√ºcker vector as ‚Ñã‚Ñã\mathcal{H} except for a larger value for p‚Äã([e]‚àí{i})ùëùdelimited-[]ùëíùëñp({[e]-\{i\}}).

If we make p‚Äã([e]‚àí{i})ùëùdelimited-[]ùëíùëñp({[e]-\{i\}}) large enough, it must appear in the cost function for ‚Ñã‚Ä≤superscript‚Ñã‚Ä≤\mathcal{H}^{\prime}. In fact, it must appear as part of a multiple tie. If it were a second maximum not equal to the maximum, then ‚Ñã‚Ä≤superscript‚Ñã‚Ä≤\mathcal{H}^{\prime} would be a better-fitting hyperplane. ‚àé

Lemma 3.9.

Let Aùê¥A be an e√óeùëíùëíe\times e matrix with entries in ‚Ñù‚à™{‚àí‚àû}‚Ñù\mathbb{R}\cup\{-\infty\} whose rows correspond to points in ‚Ñùe/‚Ñù‚Äãùüèsuperscript‚Ñùùëí‚Ñù1\mathbb{R}^{e}/\mathbb{R}{\bf 1}, and let A‚Ä≤superscriptùê¥‚Ä≤A^{\prime} be constructed from Aùê¥A as in Lemma 3.6. Then the tropical volume of Aùê¥A is a lower bound for the cost function. Furthermore, we have that ‚àëŒ±j=tdet¬†‚ÄãA‚Ä≤subscriptùõºùëótdet¬†superscriptùê¥‚Ä≤\sum{\alpha_{j}}=\text{tdet\,}A^{\prime}.

Proof.

Let ‚Ñã‚Ñã\mathcal{H} be a best-fit hyperplane in ‚Ñùe/‚Ñù‚Äãùüèsuperscript‚Ñùùëí‚Ñù1\mathbb{R}^{e}/\mathbb{R}{\bf 1} for the rows of Aùê¥A, with corresponding tropical Pl√ºcker vector pùëùp. The basic argument is as follows: we can perturb ‚Ñã‚Ñã\mathcal{H} to obtain a new best-fit hyperplane whose sum of distances to the data points given by the Red Rule is the difference of two permutations, with the larger permutation corresponding to the tropical determinant of A‚Ä≤superscriptùê¥‚Ä≤A^{\prime}.

We prove the result by induction on eùëíe. For the base case, let e=1ùëí1e=1. Then the tropical volume and the cost function are both trivial.

Suppose we have proved the lemma up to e‚àí1ùëí1e-1. We divide the situation into several possible cases. First, let there be some index kùëòk appearing only in ties in the cost function, with at most one of these appearances being a two-way tie. If kùëòk appears in a two-way tie, let D(jk)superscriptùê∑subscriptùëóùëòD^{(j_{k})} denote the corresponding datapoint. Otherwise, let D(jk)superscriptùê∑subscriptùëóùëòD^{(j_{k})} denote some datapoint for which kùëòk appears in a multiple tie.

Then we can write the cost function as

p‚Äã([e]‚àí{k})+Dk(jk)‚àíp‚Äã([e]‚àí{k})‚àíDk(jk)+‚àëj‚â†jkŒ¥j‚Äã(‚Ñã).ùëùdelimited-[]ùëíùëòsubscriptsuperscriptùê∑subscriptùëóùëòùëòùëùdelimited-[]ùëíùëòsubscriptsuperscriptùê∑subscriptùëóùëòùëòsubscriptùëósubscriptùëóùëòsubscriptùõøùëó‚Ñãp({[e]-\{k\})}+D^{(j_{k})}_{k}-p({[e]-\{k\}})-D^{(j_{k})}_{k}+\sum_{j\neq j_{k}}\delta_{j}(\mathcal{H}).

Construct the matrix A‚Ä≤‚Ä≤superscriptùê¥‚Ä≤‚Ä≤A^{\prime\prime} by deleting the kùëòkth row and jksubscriptùëóùëòj_{k}th column from A‚Ä≤superscriptùê¥‚Ä≤A^{\prime}. If ‚Ñì<e‚Ñìùëí\ell<e, and if there exists another index i‚Ñì+1subscriptùëñ‚Ñì1i_{\ell+1} which appears as a positive term in the cost function, we repeat the above argument. It therefore follows that if p‚Äã([e]‚àí{i})ùëùdelimited-[]ùëíùëñp([e]-\{i\}) appears in the cost function as part of a non-tie, it must appear at least twice as part of a non-tie or a two-way tie. By assumption, therefore, each index appears at least twice as part of a non-tie or a two-way tie.

In particular, the pigeonhole principle implies that each index iùëñi appears exactly twice as part of a non-tie or a two-way tie. It can thus be assumed that each index appears once as part of some Œ±isubscriptùõºùëñ\alpha_{i} and once as part of some Œ≤isubscriptùõΩùëñ\beta_{i}. Now the distance function d‚Äã(‚Ñã)ùëë‚Ñãd(\mathcal{H}) is the difference between two different permutations of SesubscriptùëÜùëíS_{e}. As before, ‚àëŒ±isubscriptsubscriptùõºùëñ\sum_{\alpha_{i}} must therefore equal the tropical determinant of A‚Ä≤superscriptùê¥‚Ä≤A^{\prime}, and the distance function d‚Äã(‚Ñã)ùëë‚Ñãd(\mathcal{H}) must be bounded below by the tropical volume as desired. ‚àé

Together, Lemmas 3.4 and 3.9 imply Theorem 3.3. This result provides a new interpretation for the tropical volume of a collection of eùëíe points: it measures the deviation of those points from lying on a common hyperplane. It also suggests a possible extension of the definition of a tropical volume to rectangular matrices ([6, Section 5]): the tropical volume of a ‚Äúskinny‚Äù matrix with more rows than columns could be defined as the sum of the distances of the row-points from a best-fit tropical hyperplane.

If n>eùëõùëín>e, an optimist might hope that the best-fit tropical hyperplane of nùëõn points in ‚Ñùe/‚Ñù‚Äãùüèsuperscript‚Ñùùëí‚Ñù1\mathbb{R}^{e}/\mathbb{R}{\bf 1} would again attain the tropical volume of some subset of eùëíe of those points. In fact, this does not hold even for e=3ùëí3e=3:

Example 3.10.

Consider the matrix Aùê¥A whose rows correspond to data points in ‚Ñù3/‚Ñù‚Äãùüèsuperscript‚Ñù3‚Ñù1\mathbb{R}^{3}/\mathbb{R}{\bf 1}:

A=(0‚àí2‚àí20‚àí1202‚àí1022).ùê¥matrix022012021022A=\begin{pmatrix}0&-2&-2\\ 0&-1&2\\ 0&2&-1\\ 0&2&2\end{pmatrix}.

The tropical volume of the first three points in Aùê¥A is 4, so any tropical line must attain a distance at least 4 to the four points. This is attained by the tropical line with apex at (0,2,2)022(0,2,2).

Example 3.11.

Let Aùê¥A be the following matrix whose rows correspond to data points in ‚Ñù3/‚Ñù‚Äãùüèsuperscript‚Ñù3‚Ñù1\mathbb{R}^{3}/\mathbb{R}{\bf 1}:

A=(0‚àí1‚àí302‚àí20310‚àí3‚àí1).ùê¥matrix013022031031A=\begin{pmatrix}0&-1&-3\\ 0&2&-2\\ 0&3&1\\ 0&-3&-1\end{pmatrix}.

The largest tropical volume of any choice of three rows is 2, but inspection shows that a best-fit tropical line attains a total distance of 3.

3.2 Best-fit Stiefel tropical linear spaces

In view of Theorem 3.3 and Lemma 3.4, we describe an algorithm to approximate a best-fit Stiefel tropical linear space of any given dimension. For simplicity, below we state the algorithm for a Stiefel tropical linear space of dimension 2.

Algorithm 3.12.
Stochastic optimization algorithm to fit LpsubscriptùêøùëùL_{p} to D(i)superscriptùê∑ùëñD^{(i)}.
Fix an ordered set V=(D(1),D(2),D(3))ùëâsuperscriptùê∑1superscriptùê∑2superscriptùê∑3V=(D^{(1)},D^{(2)},D^{(3)}) and compute Lp‚Äã(V)subscriptùêøùëùùëâL_{p}(V).
repeat:
¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†Sample three datapoints D(j1),D(j2),D(j3)superscriptùê∑subscriptùëó1superscriptùê∑subscriptùëó2superscriptùê∑subscriptùëó3D^{(j_{1})},D^{(j_{2})},D^{(j_{3})} randomly from the set of all datapoints.
¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†Let V‚Ä≤={D(j1),D(j2),D(j3)}superscriptùëâ‚Ä≤superscriptùê∑subscriptùëó1superscriptùê∑subscriptùëó2superscriptùê∑subscriptùëó3V^{\prime}=\{D^{(j_{1})},D^{(j_{2})},D^{(j_{3})}\}.
¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†Compute d‚Äã(Lp‚Äã(V‚Ä≤))ùëësubscriptùêøùëùsuperscriptùëâ‚Ä≤d(L_{p}(V^{\prime})).
¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†if d‚Äã(Lp‚Äã(V))>d‚Äã(Lp‚Äã(V‚Ä≤)),ùëësubscriptùêøùëùùëâùëësubscriptùêøùëùsuperscriptùëâ‚Ä≤d(L_{p}(V))>d(L_{p}(V^{\prime})), set V‚ÜêV‚Ä≤‚Üêùëâsuperscriptùëâ‚Ä≤V\leftarrow V^{\prime}.
until¬†convergence.

This algorithm attempts to minimize d‚Äã(Lp)ùëësubscriptùêøùëùd(L_{p}) by randomly varying the three points generating LpsubscriptùêøùëùL_{p} within the set of all datapoints. Whenever a choice of three points V‚Ä≤superscriptùëâ‚Ä≤V^{\prime} improves upon the current configuration VùëâV, we replace VùëâV with V‚Ä≤superscriptùëâ‚Ä≤V^{\prime}. Convergence is assessed by considering whether a new choice of VùëâV has been found over a fixed number of previous iterations; if no better VùëâV is found over some prespecified number of iterations, then the algorithm terminates.

Remark 3.13.

Algorithm 3.12 does not always attain an exact best-fit tropical linear space. This is clear, for example, if we consider a variant of the algorithm for fitting a 0-dimensional Stiefel tropical linear space, i.e., a tropical Fermat-Weber point as in [17]. In general, the collection of tropical Fermat-Weber points for a given dataset need not contain a data point.

Because the space of ultrametrics ùí∞msubscriptùí∞ùëö\mathcal{U}_{m} is a tropical linear space (Theorem 2.18), which are tropically convex, the convex hull of points in ùí∞msubscriptùí∞ùëö\mathcal{U}_{m} is contained in ùí∞msubscriptùí∞ùëö\mathcal{U}_{m}. Unfortunately, however, the Stiefel tropical linear space defined by these points may not be contained in ùí∞msubscriptùí∞ùëö\mathcal{U}_{m}.

Lemma 3.14.

Let LpsubscriptùêøùëùL_{p} be a tropical linear space and D(i)‚ààLpsuperscriptùê∑ùëñsubscriptùêøùëùD^{(i)}\in L_{p} some points in the tropical linear space. Then it need not be the case that the Stiefel tropical linear space LqsubscriptùêøùëûL_{q} defined by the points is contained in LpsubscriptùêøùëùL_{p}.

Proof.

For a very simple counterexample, let LpsubscriptùêøùëùL_{p} be the tropical line in ‚Ñù3/‚Ñù‚Äãùüèsuperscript‚Ñù3‚Ñù1\mathbb{R}^{3}/\mathbb{R}{\bf 1} centered at the origin, and take the two points D(1)=(0,‚àí1,0)superscriptùê∑1010D^{(1)}=(0,-1,0) and D(2)=(0,‚àí2,0)superscriptùê∑2020D^{(2)}=(0,-2,0). We have the picture in Figure 7.

‚àé

If our data points D(i)superscriptùê∑ùëñD^{(i)} correspond to ultrametrics, Lemma 3.14 tells us that the tropical linear space produced by Algorithm 3.12 may not be contained in the overall space of ultrametrics. Hence this approach does not apply directly to the analysis of equidistant trees.

In the proof of Lemma 3.14, however, if our two chosen points D(1)superscriptùê∑1D^{(1)} and D(2)superscriptùê∑2D^{(2)} lie on different rays of the tropical line LpsubscriptùêøùëùL_{p}, it is easy to see that their corresponding Stiefel tropical linear space will be contained in LpsubscriptùêøùëùL_{p} as well. In general, given some points D(i)superscriptùê∑ùëñD^{(i)} in a tropical linear space LpsubscriptùêøùëùL_{p}, it would be interesting to study the conditions under which their corresponding Stiefel tropical linear space LqsubscriptùêøùëûL_{q} satisfies Lq‚äÜLpsubscriptùêøùëûsubscriptùêøùëùL_{q}\subseteq L_{p}. Such a result would enable a natural extension of these methods to the study of ultrametrics.

The classical principal components have a nested structure, in which the iùëñith PCA is contained in the (i+1)ùëñ1(i+1)st PCA for each iùëñi. It is natural to wonder whether a similar relationship holds in this tropical analogue. Again, the situation is complicated.

Example 3.15.

The minimal distance of a zeroth tropical principal component, or a tropical Fermat-Weber point, is given in [17, Theorem 3].

Let D(1)=(0,‚àí2,‚àí2),D(2)=(0,‚àí1,2),formulae-sequencesuperscriptùê∑1022superscriptùê∑2012D^{(1)}=(0,-2,-2),D^{(2)}=(0,-1,2), and D(3)=(0,2,‚àí1)superscriptùê∑3021D^{(3)}=(0,2,-1). Then their tropical volume equals 4, and a tropical Fermat-Weber point attains a total distance of seven from the three points. A best-fit hyperplane is given by the line with apex at (0,1,‚àí2)012(0,1,-2), and inspection shows that no point on this line is a Fermat-Weber point.

On the other hand, the point (0,‚àí1,‚àí1)011(0,-1,-1) can be checked to be a Fermat-Weber point, and the line with apex at (0,2,‚àí1)021(0,2,-1) is a best-fit hyperplane containing that Fermat-Weber point. In other words, a best-fit tropical line need not fit a best-fit tropical point, but we can find an example in this case for which this containment holds.

4 Tropical PCA as a tropical polytope

We now discuss a different notion of a tropical principal component analysis, in which our analogue to a linear plane is a tropical polytope. Classically, the row-span of a matrix of dimensions s√óeùë†ùëís\times e defines a linear space of dimension at most sùë†s. In the tropical setting, by contrast, Section 2.1 tells us that the row-span of a tropical matrix is a tropical polytope.

A tropical principal component analysis, therefore, outputs the tropical convex hull of sùë†s points in ‚Ñùe/‚Ñù‚Äãùüèsuperscript‚Ñùùëí‚Ñù1\mathbb{R}^{e}/\mathbb{R}{\bf 1} minimizing the distances between each point in the sample to its projection onto the convex hull. For simplification, we focus on the second order principal components, noting that the following discussion could be generalized to arbitrary sùë†s. Our problem can be written as follows:

Problem 4.1.

We seek a solution for the following optimization problem:

minD(1),D(2),D(3)‚àà‚Ñùe/‚Ñù‚Äãùüè‚Äã‚àëi=1ndtr‚Äã(di,di‚Ä≤)subscriptsuperscriptùê∑1superscriptùê∑2superscriptùê∑3superscript‚Ñùùëí‚Ñù1superscriptsubscriptùëñ1ùëõsubscriptùëëtrsubscriptùëëùëñsubscriptsuperscriptùëë‚Ä≤ùëñ\min_{D^{(1)},D^{(2)},D^{(3)}\in\mathbb{R}^{e}/\mathbb{R}{\bf 1}}\sum_{i=1}^{n}d_{\rm tr}(d_{i},d^{\prime}_{i})

where

di‚Ä≤=Œª1i‚äôD(1)‚äïŒª2i‚äôD(2)‚äïŒª3i‚äôD(3),where‚ÄãŒªki=min‚Äã(di‚àíD(k)),formulae-sequencesubscriptsuperscriptùëë‚Ä≤ùëñdirect-sumdirect-productsuperscriptsubscriptùúÜ1ùëñsuperscriptùê∑1direct-productsuperscriptsubscriptùúÜ2ùëñsuperscriptùê∑2direct-productsuperscriptsubscriptùúÜ3ùëñsuperscriptùê∑3wheresuperscriptsubscriptùúÜùëòùëñminsubscriptùëëùëñsuperscriptùê∑ùëòd^{\prime}_{i}=\lambda_{1}^{i}\odot D^{(1)}\,\oplus\,\lambda_{2}^{i}\odot D^{(2)}\,\oplus\,\lambda_{3}^{i}\odot D^{(3)},\quad{\rm where}\,\,\lambda_{k}^{i}={\rm min}(d_{i}-D^{(k)}), (4)

and

(6)

In fact, this problem can be reformulated in terms of mixed integer programming.

    Œîi‚â•‚àí[di‚Äã(k)‚àídi‚Ä≤‚Äã(k)‚àídi‚Äã(l)+di‚Ä≤‚Äã(l)],subscriptŒîùëñdelimited-[]subscriptùëëùëñùëòsubscriptsuperscriptùëë‚Ä≤ùëñùëòsubscriptùëëùëñùëôsubscriptsuperscriptùëë‚Ä≤ùëñùëô\displaystyle\Delta_{i}\geq-[d_{i}(k)-d^{{}^{\prime}}_{i}(k)-d_{i}(l)+d^{{}^{\prime}}_{i}(l)], 1‚â§k<l‚â§e.1ùëòùëôùëí\displaystyle 1\leq k<l\leq e.

Remark 4.3.

Projecting onto a tropical polytope is relatively straightforward compared to projecting onto a tropical linear space (compare Formula 2 and Theorems 2.7 and 2.8). In theory, one could attempt to reformulate the Stiefel tropical linear space optimization problem from Section 3 as in Proposition 4.2; however, the increased complexity of the linear space projection map makes this impractical.

Due to the large number of variables and constraints involved in Proposition 4.2, we are able to solve only relatively small cases like Example 5.1 below in a reasonable amount of time.

4.1 Heuristic approximation

As noted above, the number of variables in the mixed integer linear programming problem in Proposition 4.2 increases quickly with the number of leaves and data points. Because solving mixed linear integer programming is NP-hard [15], this problem is difficult to solve in practice. In analogy with Algorithm 3.12, therefore, we develop a heuristic method for approximating the optimal solution for the problem in Proposition 4.2.

Algorithm 4.4 (Approximation for the second order PCA as a tropical polytope).
Stochastic optimization algorithm to fit ùí´ùí´\mathcal{P} to D(i)superscriptùê∑ùëñD^{(i)}.
Fix an ordered set V=(D(1),D(2),D(3))ùëâsuperscriptùê∑1superscriptùê∑2superscriptùê∑3V=(D^{(1)},D^{(2)},D^{(3)}) and compute ùí´=tconv‚Äã(V)ùí´tconvùëâ\mathcal{P}=\text{tconv}(V).
repeat:
¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†Sample three datapoints D(j1),D(j2),D(j3)superscriptùê∑subscriptùëó1superscriptùê∑subscriptùëó2superscriptùê∑subscriptùëó3D^{(j_{1})},D^{(j_{2})},D^{(j_{3})} randomly from the set of all datapoints.
¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†Let V‚Ä≤={D(j1),D(j2),D(j3)}superscriptùëâ‚Ä≤superscriptùê∑subscriptùëó1superscriptùê∑subscriptùëó2superscriptùê∑subscriptùëó3V^{\prime}=\{D^{(j_{1})},D^{(j_{2})},D^{(j_{3})}\}.
¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†Compute d‚Äã(ùí´‚Ä≤)=d‚Äã(tconv‚Äã(V‚Ä≤))ùëësuperscriptùí´‚Ä≤ùëëtconvsuperscriptùëâ‚Ä≤d(\mathcal{P}^{\prime})=d(\text{tconv}(V^{\prime})).
¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†if d‚Äã(ùí´)>d‚Äã(ùí´‚Ä≤),ùëëùí´ùëësuperscriptùí´‚Ä≤d(\mathcal{P})>d(\mathcal{P}^{\prime}), set V‚ÜêV‚Ä≤‚Üêùëâsuperscriptùëâ‚Ä≤V\leftarrow V^{\prime}.
until¬†convergence.

As before, convergence can be assessed by considering whether a new choice of VùëâV has been found over a fixed number of previous iterations. If computational time is limited, another approach might simply be to prespecify a total number tùë°t of samples. And of course, when the computational cost is reasonable one could enumerate through all (n3)binomialùëõ3\binom{n}{3} different choices for the generating points of ùí´ùí´\mathcal{P} instead of sampling.

Remark 4.5.

Three data points D(j1),D(j2),superscriptùê∑subscriptùëó1superscriptùê∑subscriptùëó2D^{(j_{1})},D^{(j_{2})}, and D(j3)superscriptùê∑subscriptùëó3D^{(j_{3})} define both a Stiefel tropical linear space LpsubscriptùêøùëùL_{p} and a tropical polytope ùí´ùí´\mathcal{P}. Because Stiefel tropical linear spaces are tropically convex, and each of the generating points is contained in LpsubscriptùêøùëùL_{p}, we see that ùí´‚äÜLpùí´subscriptùêøùëù\mathcal{P}\subseteq L_{p}. In particular, given the same convergence criteria, we should expect Algorithm 3.12 to provide a somewhat better fit than Algorithm 4.4.

Remark 4.6.

Note that Algorithm 4.4 is well-suited for applications to phylogenetics. Because ùí∞msubscriptùí∞ùëö\mathcal{U}_{m} is a tropical linear space (Theorem 2.18) and tropical linear spaces are tropically convex, the solution set ùí´=tconv‚Äã(D(1),D(2),D(3))ùí´tconvsuperscriptùê∑1superscriptùê∑2superscriptùê∑3\mathcal{P}=\text{tconv}(D^{(1)},D^{(2)},D^{(3)}) obtained from Algorithm 4.4 will be contained in the space of ultrametrics. In particular, projections of ultrametrics are also ultrametrics.

5 Simulations

In this section, we apply the previous results to simulated datasets coming from phylogenetics.

5.1 Exact methods

We begin by identifying the exact best-fit tropical polytope with three vertices closest to a small dataset of equidistant trees using Proposition 4.2. We implemented this proposition mainly based on a R interface to the popular optimization software IBM ILOG CPLEX, called cplexAPI.

Example 5.1.

We randomly generated 6 equidistant trees with 3 leaves and computed their vectorized distance matrices in Figure 10 and Table 10.

Using our optimization problem formulation from Proposition 4.2, we obtain D(1),D(2),D(3)superscriptùê∑1superscriptùê∑2superscriptùê∑3D^{(1)},D^{(2)},D^{(3)} for this example. These points are ultrametrics, and they are described in Figure 12 and Table 12. In fact, in this case the best-fit tropical polytope contains all the equidistant trees, so that the sum of distances is zero.

5.2 Approximative algorithms

For larger datasets, we turn to the approximative Algorithms 3.12 and 4.4. We implemented both algorithms in R.111Our software for all computations can be downloaded at http://polytopes.net/computations/tropicalPCA/. We then generated a random sample from Mesquite [11] and applied our algorithms on this dataset. The sample was constructed as follows:

Algorithm 5.2 (Generating the simulation dataset).
  1. 1.

    Generate 250 gene trees with 8 leaves from the coalescent model under a fixed species tree with depth equal to 10

  2. 2.

    Transform the gene trees to be ultrametrics.

  3. 3.

    Compute approximate second order tropical principal components via the Algorithms 3.12 and 4.4.

We applied both methods of tropical principal component analysis to a set of random trees generated by Algorithm 5.2. In analogy with [20], we define summary statistics to describe the fit of a Stiefel tropical linear space or a tropical polytope to a given data set. If LpsubscriptùêøùëùL_{p} is a Stiefel tropical linear space, we define its distance to the datapoints d‚Äã(Lp)ùëësubscriptùêøùëùd(L_{p}) as

d‚Äã(Lp)=‚àëid‚Äã(D(i),Lp),ùëësubscriptùêøùëùsubscriptùëñùëësuperscriptùê∑ùëñsubscriptùêøùëùd(L_{p})=\sum_{i}d(D^{(i)},L_{p}),

and a tropical proportion of variance statistic

r‚Äã(Lp)=‚àëidt‚Äãr‚Äã(œÄ¬Ø,œÄLp‚Äã(D(i)))‚àëidt‚Äãr(D(i),œÄLp(D(i))+‚àëidt‚Äãr(œÄ¬Ø,œÄLp(D(i)))r(L_{p})=\frac{\sum_{i}d_{tr}(\bar{\pi},\pi_{L_{p}}(D^{(i)}))}{\sum_{i}d_{tr}(D^{(i)},\pi_{L_{p}}(D^{(i)})+\sum_{i}d_{tr}(\bar{\pi},\pi_{L_{p}}(D^{(i)}))}

where œÄ¬Ø¬Øùúã\bar{\pi} denotes a Fermat-Weber point of the projections of the datapoints, as in [17]. These statistics are defined analogously for a tropical polytope ùí´ùí´\mathcal{P}. The statistic r‚Äã(Lp)ùëüsubscriptùêøùëùr(L_{p}) can be interpreted as the proportion of variance explained by LpsubscriptùêøùëùL_{p}; in order to remain consistent with the tropical metric, we sum distances rather than squared distances.

For the polytopal approach, as noted above, the projections will remain ultrametrics. We therefore analyze the topologies of these projections, and compare them with the topology of the species tree.

5.3 Approximation results

We applied Algorithm 3.12 to find an approximate 2-dimensional best-fit Stiefel tropical linear space with a convergence threshold of 100 iterations. The summary statistics for this run were: d‚Äã(Lp)=363.0378ùëësubscriptùêøùëù363.0378d(L_{p})=363.0378 and r‚Äã(Lp)=0.322ùëüsubscriptùêøùëù0.322r(L_{p})=0.322.

We also applied a variant of Algorithm 4.4 to find an approximate best-fit tropical polytope with three vertices, in which we enumerated through all (2503)binomial2503\binom{250}{3} different choices. The summary statistics were: d‚Äã(ùí´)=360.6831ùëëùí´360.6831d(\mathcal{P})=360.6831 and r‚Äã(ùí´)=0.265ùëüùí´0.265r(\mathcal{P})=0.265. We note that the overall sum of distances is similar between the two methods, but that the best-fit Stiefel tropical linear space explains a slightly higher proportion of variance.

For the tropical polytope method, we recall that projections of equidistant trees will remain ultrametrics. We present common topologies of the projections as well as the species tree topology in Figure 13.222Tree topologies of all projected points can be found in the supplement at http://polytopes.net/computations/tropicalPCA/. We observe that these topologies of projected trees are broadly consistent with the topology of the species tree under which these gene trees were generated: taxa gùëîg and cùëêc group together, as do taxa h‚Ñéh and fùëìf, and the four taxa aùëéa, bùëèb, dùëëd, eùëíe also group together. We can view our best-fit tropical polytope as preserving these features of the species tree, meaning that this tropical polytope retains information after projection.

6 Apicomplexa genome

We also applied our tropical principal component algorithms to a set of trees constructed from 252 orthologous sequences on eight species of protozoa in the Apicomplexa phylum by [12]. This dataset was also analyzed by Weyenberg et.¬†al; one can find more details, such as the gene sequences, in [25]. Because ordinary PCA is sensitive to outliers, we removed 16 outlier gene trees identified by [25] before fitting the tropical principal components.

To find an approximate best-fit 2-dimensional Stiefel tropical linear space, we applied Algorithm 3.12 with a convergence threshold of 100 iterations. Due to the stochastic nature of the algorithm, we executed the algorithm three times. The summary statistics remained consistent between these runs. For one representative execution, these statistics were: d‚Äã(Lp)=145.38ùëësubscriptùêøùëù145.38d(L_{p})=145.38 and r‚Äã(Lp)=0.616ùëüsubscriptùêøùëù0.616r(L_{p})=0.616.

We also applied a variant of Algorithm 4.4 to find a well-fitted tropical polytope with three vertices, enumerating through all (2523)binomial2523{\binom{252}{3}} possibilities. The summary statistics for this run were: d‚Äã(ùí´)=147.0568ùëëùí´147.0568d(\mathcal{P})=147.0568 and r‚Äã(ùí´)=0.612ùëüùí´0.612r(\mathcal{P})=0.612. We note that these summary statistics are relatively consistent with the summary statistics obtained from the Stiefel tropical linear space algorithm.

The tree topologies are presented in Figure 14. In general, the projected topologies were largely congruent with the generally accepted phylogeny: the two Plasmodium species (Pv and Pf) group together, as do the four species Ta, Bb, Tg, and Et, and Tt is isolated on a deep branch.

[10, Theorem 23] tells us the tropical convex hull of the rows and columns of a matrix are equal. This allows us to visualize our best-fit tropical polytope in the two-dimensional plane ‚Ñù3/‚Ñù‚Äãùüèsuperscript‚Ñù3‚Ñù1\mathbb{R}^{3}/\mathbb{R}{\bf 1} as the tropical convex hull of 28 points. These 28 points divide the polytope into different cells, as described in [14, Example 9]. We plot this polytope, along with its cells and the projections of our data points, in Figure 15. We note that the different topologies seem to divide the tropical polytope PCA into several regions of positive area.

7 Discussion

In recent decades, the field of phylogenetics has found applications in the analysis on genomic scale data. In particular, phylogenetic methods have been used to analyze the relationship between species and populations, as well as the evolutionary processes of speciation and molecular evolution. As the cost of generating genomic data continues to decrease, the sheer volume of genomic data demands new analysis techniques. Motivated by this problem from systematic biology, we introduced in this paper a tropical analogue to principal component analysis in the tropical projective torus.

Compared to the classical case, there is still much to be understood about these tropical principal component analyses. For example, there is a nested structure to the classical principal components: the zeroth order PCA is contained by the first order PCA; the first order PCA is contained by the second order PCA; and so on. It is unclear whether a similar relationship holds in the tropical analogue, either as a Stiefel tropical linear space or as a tropical polytope. We found examples of best-fit Stiefel tropical linear spaces which do not contain tropical Fermat-Weber points, such as Example 3.15. In each such case, however, there existed another tropical linear space of equally good fit that did contain a tropical Fermat-Weber point. Because these best-fit tropical structures are in general not unique, it is possible that one could define the principal components so that this containment property holds. Future work could explore this question further.

We also introduced some approximative methods to compute the second order tropical PCA as a Stiefel tropical linear space and tropical polytope. Both algorithms rely on the uniform sampling of three random points from the dataset. However, uniform sampling may not be the most efficient approach to finding a well-fitted solution. One might explore improvements to these algorithms using different sampling methods, such as the Metropolis-Hasting algorithm or Gibb sampling. [26]

In [20], the authors considered the Billera-Holmes-Vogtman (BHV) [3] metric on the tree space and defined the (s‚àí1)ùë†1(s-1)st order PCA as the locus of the weighted Fr√©chet mean of sùë†s distinct points in the tree space. Nye et.¬†al did not use a convex hull of sùë†s distinct points in the tree space under the BHV metric because Lin et.¬†al showed in [16] that the dimension of the convex hull under the BHV metric can be arbitrary high. In contrast, our methods for tropical principal component analysis are well-behaved with respect to dimension: the Stiefel tropical linear space given by an (s√óe)ùë†ùëí(s\times e)-dimensional matrix will be of dimension s‚àí1ùë†1s-1, and the tropical convex hull of sùë†s points has dimension at most s‚àí1ùë†1s-1 as well. [18, Theorem 5.3.23] In statistics, we often use different metrics to analyze empirical data sets. Our methods provide a new approach to analyzing phylogenetic tree datasets which may be particularly suitable in certain situations.

In this work, we also found an exact solution for the best-fit tropical hyperplane of eùëíe points in ‚Ñùe/‚Ñù‚Äãùüèsuperscript‚Ñùùëí‚Ñù1\mathbb{R}^{e}/\mathbb{R}{\bf 1}. The general problem of constructing a best-fit Stiefel tropical linear space of given dimension remains unsolved. In addition, given nùëõn points in a tropical linear space LpsubscriptùêøùëùL_{p}, we noted that the Stiefel tropical linear space defined by these nùëõn points may not be contained in LpsubscriptùêøùëùL_{p}. Understanding the conditions under which containment holds could enable further application of these techniques to phylogenetics.
